title: Technical Interview Hazing
context: Tech companies use algorithmic coding challenges (LeetCode-style problems) as the primary filter for engineering hires. The practice started at Google and spread industry-wide. Candidates spend months grinding algorithm problems that have no relationship to their daily work. Companies filter out experienced engineers who can't reverse a binary tree on a whiteboard while hiring puzzle-solvers who can't design a production system. The interview process selects for interview preparation skill, not engineering ability.
hypothesis: Algorithmic coding interviews identify the best software engineers.

chain.root: Use LeetCode-style interviews as primary hiring filter

effects.label: Selects for interview preparation, not engineering skill
effects.impact: Correlation between interview score and job performance: 0.1-0.3

children.label: Candidates with 3 months of LeetCode prep outperform 10-year veterans
System design, debugging, and collaboration skills go unmeasured
New grads with time to prep are advantaged over working professionals

effects.label: Experienced engineers opt out of the process

children.label: Staff engineers refuse to grind LeetCode — they have better options
Companies miss domain experts who can't solve dynamic programming on demand
Hiring pool skews young and inexperienced

effects.label: Massive candidate time waste at industry scale
effects.impact: 100-300 hours of prep per candidate, millions of candidates

children.label: A $50B+ industry of prep courses, books, and platforms
Candidates from lower-income backgrounds can't afford months of unpaid prep
The prep time could be spent building actual projects or contributing to open source

effects.label: Homogeneous teams result from homogeneous filtering
effects.impact: Diversity decreases as process favors specific backgrounds

children.label: CS degree holders advantaged — self-taught engineers filtered out
Career changers and non-traditional backgrounds systematically excluded

dontIf: Your engineering work doesn't involve implementing algorithms from scratch
You're struggling to attract senior or diverse engineering talent
ifYouMust: Limit algorithmic questions to 20% of the interview — test other skills too
Allow candidates to use their preferred language and look up syntax
Evaluate problem-solving approach, not memorized solutions
Provide problems in advance to reduce prep anxiety and test real thinking

alternatives.name: Work sample tests
alternatives.note: Give candidates a realistic task similar to actual work — review a PR, debug an issue, design a feature

alternatives.name: Paid trial projects
alternatives.note: 1-2 day paid project that simulates real work — best predictor of job performance

alternatives.name: Portfolio and past work review
alternatives.note: Evaluate what candidates have actually built rather than what they can solve under pressure

falsifiability: LeetCode-style interview scores correlate with on-the-job performance at r > 0.5 across a large sample
